The "Declaration of Official Language Act of 2001" establishes English as the official language of the government. The "Declaration of Official Language Act of 2001" establishes English as the official language of the United States government and emphasizes the preservation and enhancement of English as the official language. No person has the right to demand government services in any language other than English, unless specified by law. The "Declaration of Official Language Act of 2001" establishes English as the official language of the United States government. All citizens are encouraged to read, write, and speak English. Fluency in English is a requirement for full citizenship, and naturalization ceremonies must be conducted in English. Exceptions to this rule do not entitle individuals to additional services in any language other than English. The chapter outlines exceptions to using languages other than English for specific purposes such as religious, training, non-English terms in government documents, law enforcement, and scientific terminology. It also states that the chapter preempts any federal law inconsistent with it, is not intended to affect language learning programs in schools, and allows for civil action in case of violations. In any action under this chapter, the court may allow a prevailing party, other than the United States, a reasonable attorney's fee as part of costs. No agency or department of the United States shall require communication in any language other than English. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF BILINGUAL EDUCATION ACT. The Bilingual Education Act (20 U.S.C. 7401 et seq.) is repealed, along with the termination of the Office of Bilingual Education and Minority Languages Affairs in the Department of Education. Unobligated funds will be deposited in the general fund of the Treasury at the end of the transition period. Transitional provisions ensure completion of programs during the current school year. The Bilingual Education Act (20 U.S.C. 7401 et seq.) will not apply until the completion of the most recent school year after the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Education may assist in transitioning children to special alternative instructional programs that do not use the student's native language. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION: States and local educational agencies are not required to implement bilingual education programs.

SEC. 5. RELEASE FROM DECREE: Any consent decree mandating bilingual education is void.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE: The Act will take effect upon enactment.

SEC. 7. REPEAL OF BILINGUAL VOTING REQUIREMENTS. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended by repealing bilingual election requirements in Section 203 and striking subsection (f) in Section 4. Conforming amendments remove references to Section 203 and Section 7 in various sections of the Act. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended by removing bilingual election requirements in Section 203 and striking subsection (f) in Section 4, which includes guarantees related to voting rights. Amendments also remove references to Section 203 and Section 7 in various sections of the Act.
